title: 'How to Hold a Grudge' Review: Bitter Is Better
summary: Grudges are natural and human, and we shouldn't feel guilty about having them. "The past matters," the author tells us. Jenny Allen reviews "How to Hold a Grudge" by Sophie Hannah.. I'm guessing Sophie Hannah had a moment-one that came after reading a few too many self-help books on mindfulness, compassion, connection to all living creatures and nonattachment to negative thoughts. And in that moment she said to herself, "Oh, for God's sake."

title: New York City's Murder Rate Hit Low in 2018
summary: Mayor Bill de Blasio says it was the fewest number of homicides in nearly 70 years. New York City set a new standard for safety last year, with its third straight year of falling murders, city officials said on Thursday.

title: Hassett Warns Other Firms Could Join Apple in Seeing Weaker Sales
summary: Kevin Hassett says U.S. economy to grow at a sturdy pace, but multinational firms with profits in China may see revenues 'sour a bit'. U.S. companies that rely heavily on sales in Chinese markets are likely to face headwinds in the months ahead amid slower growth and rising trade tensions, a top White House economic adviser said Thursday, as U.S. negotiators prepare for a round of talks in China.

title: Xi's Promise to Taiwan Sounds Like a Threat
summary: China's president cites Hong Kong's system as a model.. Xi Jinping wants to coax Taiwan into "national reunification." The Chinese president gave a speech Wednesday touting "one country, two systems"-the Hong Kong model-as a basis for cross-strait relations. In 2017 Mr. Xi claimed Hong Kong enjoys "more extensive democratic rights and freedoms than at any other time in its history." The argument was strained even then, and civil liberties only regressed in 2018.

title: A Nuclear Battle Is Ahead in Congress
summary: Democrats seem intent on killing the main elements of the Pentagon's plan to modernize the arsenal.. For the first time in decades, a major political fight is brewing over America's nuclear deterrent. Rep. Adam Smith of Washington, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, seems intent on killing several main elements of the Pentagon's modernization plan-especially two weapons projects intended to deter Russia and China.

title: The Nation of Islam and the House
summary: Democratic leadership members have a history with Louis Farrakhan.. Donald Trump has repeatedly faced calls to disavow anti-Semites, but Democrats have their own anti-Semitism problem. The new House majority leadership includes several lawmakers with ties to the nation of Islam's Louis Farrakhan:

title: Another Religious Test in the Senate
summary: Two Democrats suggest a judicial nominee must quit a Catholic organization.. People often assumed that prejudice against Catholic politicians ended with the election of John F. Kennedy. Yet anti-Catholic bigotry is still with us. On Dec. 5 U.S. senators sent written questions to Brian Buescher, an Omaha, Neb., lawyer recently nominated by President Trump to sit on the U.S. District Court in Nebraska. Amid queries about judicial philosophy, two Democratic senators demanded answers about Mr. Buescher's membership in the Knights of Columbus, a 140-year-old Catholic service organization.

title: Save America From Aunt Sally
summary: What Twain can tell us about the imbalance between American democracy's twin stars.. Imagine American politics as a system of binary stars, one Republican-conservative, the other Democratic-progressive. The stars are separate from each other, yet not independent. They are bound together by mutual gravity-orbiting around a common center of mass-and by their history of reciprocating opposition. Twin masses of flaming, superheated gas act to discipline one another: a system of checks and balances.

title: Italy's 'Doom Loops,' Imagined and Real
summary: The financial system isn't about to collapse. But the nation's economy faces a death spiral.. That silence you hear is the European Central Bank not buying more government and commercial bonds. Its controversial quantitative-easing program mostly ended Dec. 31, although ECB President Mario Draghi will continue reinvesting the proceeds of maturing holdings indefinitely.

title: Elizabeth Warren's Money Game
summary: She collects cash, then demands her opponents disavow the methods she used.. Sen. Elizabeth Warren built a political career on her reputation as a financial expert. Her prospective presidential opponents are learning how savvy she is, at least when it comes to campaign cash.

title: Baby, There's a Chilling Effect Outside
summary: Political correctness could destroy the arts and entertainment. Only the left can defeat it.. My greatest hope for 2019 is cultural. It is that the left will rise and do what only it can do-strike a blow against political correctness in the arts and entertainment. All artists are meant to be free and daring. Their job, whether in drama, comedy or music, is to approach the truth-to apprehend it, get their hands on it and hold it up for a moment for everyone to see. That's a big job, a great one, and you can do it only if you're brave. Pope John Paul II, in his 1999 Letter to Artists, noted something I have witnessed: The artist faces a constant sense of defeat. You're working, you're trying, but it's never as good as you wanted, as you dreamed. Even your most successful work only comes close. Artists are looking for "the hidden meaning of things." Their "intuitions" spring from their souls. There is an "unbridgeable gap" between what they produce and "the dazzling perfection" of what they glimpsed in the creative moment. They forge on anyway.

title: Car Sales Keep Pace in 2018, Defying Predictions of a Downturn
summary: The industry sold about 17.3 million vehicles last year. U.S. auto sales held steady last year despite predictions the market would cool, capping the best four-year period ever for the industry.

title: Who's Who in the New Congress
summary: Democrat Pelosi leads a House with a record number of women; Republican-controlled Senate welcomes several new faces and shifts panel chiefs. The 116th session of Congress convened Thursday, with Democrats taking control of the House and Republicans expanding on their slim majority in the Senate.

title: Square Chooses Blizzard Entertainment Executive to be New CFO
summary: Amrita Ahuja fills role as finance chief after departure of Sarah Friar in October. Square Inc. said Thursday that Amrita Ahuja agreed to join the financial-technology company as chief financial officer starting later this month.

title: Stocks Fall After Apple Sales Warning
summary: Dow industrials fall 2.8% while S&P declines 2.5%; Apple shares drop 10%. U.S. stocks tumbled Thursday, as weak economic data and a rare sales warning from Apple sparked fresh worries among investors about a global slowdown.

USAA Federal Savings Bank will pay more than $12 million to over 66,000 customers-and pay a $3.5 million fine-after it failed to stop payments or resolve errors involving preauthorized electronic fund transfers, according to a settlement announced by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

summary: The U.S. dollar declined Thursday after a report showed a deceleration in factory activity. The U.S. dollar declined Thursday after a report showed a deceleration in factory activity as trade tensions contributed to a reduction in demand for goods made in America.

summary: Total returns for Treasury inflation-protected securities finish 2018 down 1.4%, data show.

summary: His firm, Third Point, takes positions in companies and advocates for change. Activist hedge-fund firm Third Point LLC lost about 11% last year, its worst performance since 2008.

summary: Investors focused on indications major oil producers are reducing output as promised. • Oil prices ended higher for a fourth straight session Thursday as investors shrugged off declines on Wall Street and focused instead on indications major oil producers, including Saudi Arabia, are reducing output as promised.

title: Facebook Begins New Year in Fixer-Upper Mode
summary: Social-media giant strives to balance its push for growth with a commitment to improve security across platforms. One year ago Friday, Mark Zuckerbergset his sights on "fixing" Facebook Inc. That remains very much a work in progress.

title: I Won't Whine About LeBron's Wine
summary: The game's most powerful athlete knows how powerful he is. If you want an indignant sports column chastising LeBron James for walking into a basketball arena carrying a glass of wine-How dare you treat a sacred NBA space like a downtown art opening-you're in the wrong spot, buddy.

title: States Appeal Ruling Invalidating Affordable Care Act
summary: Appeal by 16 states and Washington, D.C., marks next stage in legal battle over health law. Sixteen states on Thursday appealed a Texas judge's ruling that invalidated the Affordable Care Act, opening the next phase of legal proceedings over the fate of the Obama-era health-care law.

title: 'Stan & Ollie' Review: Fat, Lean, Funny and Fine
summary: Jon S. Baird's biopic sheds new light on the comedy duo Laurel & Hardy through a little-known tour toward the end of their professional lives.. 'Stan & Ollie" turns the conventions of a biopic into a fond tribute to the deathless comedy team of Laurel & Hardy. Among its abundant charms are the fragments of shtick the pair perform blithely, almost unconsciously, in their offstage lives-Ollie (John C. Reilly), doing his delicate little dance steps, Stan (Steve Coogan) scratching his head in mock perplexity. The real head-scratcher is how such an endearingly modest, gentle film can say so much with such eloquence about a professional partnership that amounts to a love affair; about the mysterious business of being funny; and about the toll taken by the passage of time. (Messrs. Reilly and Coogan are both wonderful; so are Shirley Henderson and Nina Arianda as, respectively, Ollie's wife, Lucille, and Stan's wife, Ida.)

title: Apple's Stock Drops on Revenue Warning
summary: Shares of suppliers including Micron Technology, Cirrus Logic and Lumentum also took hits. Apple Inc. shares fell 10% Thursday after the iPhone maker slashed its quarterly revenue forecast for the first time in more than 15 years as it deals with shrinking demand in China and fewer owners upgrading their phones.

summary: Resume Subscription. Bain Capital's impact investment fund has acquired HealthDrive Corp., a provider of on-site dentistry, podiatry and other services to residents in extended care facilities.

summary: Companies that once gobbled up foreclosed suburban homes are now acquiring new ones for the rental market. Millennials aren't the only ones having a hard time finding houses to buy. So is Wall Street.

summary: I knew always to have refreshments handy.. Chris Kornelis's op-ed "Rediscover the Art of the Pop-In," brought me back to my "A ha!" moment regarding being prepared for company (Dec. 28).

title: Williamsburg Breathes Sigh of Relief After L-Train News
summary: Some residents express skepticism that repairs will be done on time, without major disruptions. Williamsburg businesses and L-train riders expressed relief and skepticism Thursday following Gov. Andrew Cuomo's announcement that the subway line would remain open during repairs.

title: 'USS Indianapolis: The Final Chapter' Review: The Depths of Tragedy
summary: This PBS documentary recounts the story of the ill-fated cruiser and a recent expedition that uncovered the wreckage.. It seems a pretty good bet that if people are familiar with the tale of the USS Indianapolis they've also seen "Jaws." During the famous, half-drunken soliloquy by the film's ornery seadog and Navy vet, Captain Quint (Robert Shaw), we get a first-person account of the ship's last voyage: The Japanese torpedoes. The cruiser sinking in 12 minutes. The surviving sailors being cast into the sea. Five days of being picked off by sharks. What makes the scene even scarier-scarier, it can be argued, than any fish in the movie-is the look on the face of oceanographer Matt Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) who sits by silently, knowing the story but looking terrified about where Quint is going to take it.

title: KKR to Invest $1 Billion in Commercial Aircraft
summary: Private-equity firm to acquire a 50% stake in Altavair, amid push to build portfolio of leased planes. KKR & Co. intends to invest an initial $1 billion in a commercial aircraft venture as part of a push by the private-equity firm into the fast-growing jet-rental business.

title: Petrobras's New CEO Promises to Continue Cutting Costs
summary: Roberto Castello Branco took office at helm of the Brazilian oil giant on Thursday. SÃO PAULO-Brazilian state-controlled oil giant Petrobras 's new chief executive officer, Roberto Castello Branco, took office on Thursday and promised to continue the job of cutting debt, selling assets and reducing costs begun by his immediate predecessors.

title: Neoclassical Chinoiserie in one of Jersey City's Priciest Bedrooms
summary: A couple spent $88,000 decorating the master bedroom of Jersey City's most expensive single-family home, mixing Asian touches like bamboo with a French-bed reproduction. Where a single-story cinder block motorcycle garage once stood is now a three-story, four-bedroom home that became the most expensive single-family residence in Jersey City, N.J, when it recently sold for $2.25 million to a couple with a young child. The owners-he's a technology executive, she's in human resources-brought in designer Mitchell Turnbough to make over the space.

title: The Rush of Bodysurfing in Rio: A Traveler's Guide
summary: The steeliest surfers in Rio de Janeiro forgo the board. To follow suit, don a pair of fins and jump in head first. THERE'S AN underground scene in Rio de Janeiro that starts early, like 5:30 a.m. Sometimes it begins the night before, when 50-odd bodysurfers who form a WhatsApp group are sharing pictures from the day-a baldheaded, wetsuit-clad wave-rider flying Superman-like across bottle-green water; a group shot of well over 100 exultant bodysurfers in sungas (like Speedos), swim fins flung skyward. The early-morning messages report surf conditions at various beaches: "Leme is firing." "Diabo looking good!"

title: Shutdown Is a Terror for Every Swamp Dweller
summary: Start phasing out discretionary programs that as of now are still being funded.. In "The Hidden Cost of a Government Shutdown," Paul C. Light chastises White House budget director Mick Mulvaney for allegedly understating the shutdown's impact (op-ed, Dec. 28). Mr. Light questions Mr. Mulvaney's lack of attention to the many private contractors who do business with the government and who lose income during a shutdown. In doing so Mr. Light has, unintentionally I assume, highlighted the core problem with unwieldy government.

title: Hospitals See Opportunity in Bringing Facilities to Patients
summary: Hospital for Special Surgery's strategy is to multiply; CEO says 'there's more demand because people are more active'. For most hospital systems, growth comes through mergers or an acquisition. But when there isn't another system to acquire, one answer is to multiply.

title: First Make the Right Call, Then 'Do No Harm'
summary: The U.S. health-care system can sometimes reward my fellow cardiologists for this sort of inaccuracy.. Regarding Kyle Clark and Andrew George's "A Second Opinion Becomes a Guilty Verdict" (op-ed, Dec. 28): The authors point out that physicians can have differing opinions, which is obvious. Yet when it comes to determining the amount of narrowing visible in a coronary angiography, Messrs. Clark and George don't distinguish between "having an opinion" and making an objective measurement. They defend physicians who do not do the math and rely on their eyeballs only.

title: As Mayor, Bloomberg Was a Centrist in Name Only
summary: He expressed an almost dictatorial leftist mindset on issues of import to him, including the environment.. An over-under on how much Michael Bloomberg might spend in pursuit of the presidency is a fun parlor game ("Take the Over on Bloomberg," editorial, Dec. 29). But to encourage a Bloomberg run as a "centrist" is to ignore his years as mayor. During his reign he expressed an almost dictatorial leftist mindset on issues of import to him, including the environment, education, gun control, people's diets and a dozen other subjects.

Thanks to a flurry of national attention, including a Best New Restaurant nod from Bon Appetit magazine, the 40-seat space is booked through the end of March, said chefs Colin Stringer and Jeremy Wolfe.

summary: Top News & Alerts. "Europe's social contracts have a common backbone-they are based on a long-established inclusive growth model characterized by a more egalitarian view of revenue generation and distribution," Jacques Bughin and Christopher Pissarides write in a VoxEU column. "However, in recent years, the economic crisis has put significant strain on this model, especially for the Mediterranean cluster." The authors write that "new McKinsey Global Institute research suggests that the upward pressure on inequality could...intensify as the result of the interaction of six global trends that are coming of age at the same time. The six trends...

title: The Fun New Corolla Hatchback Puts the Toy in Toyota
summary: The Toyota Corolla Hatchback's cheerfully modern design, its fleet of high-tech options and the soothing distraction of a manually shifted car will have you wanting to work on your heel-and-toe footwork, says Dan Neil. HERE'S A LITTLE JEWEL box of antiquarianism: A hatchback, a real hatchback economy car, with a naturally aspirated four-cylinder engine bolted to a six-speed manual transmission (a CVT automatic is an $1,100 option). All you car guys who would bag on our little 168-hp friend here, understand that the young person who buys the new Toyota Corolla Hatchback knows how to drive a stick shift, which puts him or her among the elite of their cohort. Maybe 20% of the U.S. population knows how and most of them are boomers who'd rather not. Among those under 25, a reasonable guess might be 10%? Anyway, it will be a small number of young contrarians who buy this car with a stick. Let's give them a round of applause.

title: American Detained in Russia Is Charged With Espionage
summary: A lawyer for Paul Whelan asked a court to free his client on bail, on an accusation Russia hasn't detailed. MOSCOW-Russia charged an American citizen who is detained in Moscow with espionage and said he can be held for up to two months, Russian state media reported Thursday.

summary: From the power and peril of popular employees to how even recent grads should be negotiating for salaries.. In 2018, the WSJ Experts wrote about compensation and the gender gap, and making meaningful small talk with employees.

title: The Great Unloved American Economy
summary: Financial markets signal trouble ahead, but the latest NFIB employer survey says it's still a job seeker's market.. Stocks have been selling off today thanks to a revenue warning from Apple and a report of slower growth in U.S. manufacturing. But the latest jobs survey from the National Federation of Independent Business, due out later today, shows a historically vibrant labor market among small firms. "Job creation was solid in December with a net addition of 0.25 workers per firm," says NFIB chief economist William Dunkelberg. This figure is up from 0.19 in November and represents the best reading since July.

title: FullBeauty Says It Will File for Bankruptcy With Lender Deal in Hand

title: Mediterranean Migration to Europe Drops Sharply
summary: EU countries' continuing attempts to reduce migration flows are taking effect, U.N. data suggest. Fewer migrants crossed, and drowned in, the Mediterranean in 2018 than the previous year, new United Nations data show, reflecting European countries' continuing attempts to reduce the flow of refugees from Africa and the Middle East that have caused political ructions in much of Europe.

title: Socialists Are No Strangers to Congress
summary: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez isn't the first self-described socialist elected to the House. Her predecessors include reformists and Soviet sympathizers.. 'Why Is There No Socialism in the United States?" asked the German sociologist Werner Sombart in a famous 1906 essay. He wanted to figure out why European countries had developed influential left-wing political movements but the U.S. hadn't. His answer: The relative affluence of American workers blunted revolutionary impulses. "On the shoals of roast beef and apple pie," he wrote, "socialist utopias are sent to their doom."

title: NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine on Life off Earth
summary: The former Oklahoma congressman wants to make space accessible to everyone-and (possibly) discover life on other planets. Big things are happening beyond Earth. China landed a probe on the "dark side" of the moon Thursday morning Beijing time, becoming the first country to touch down on the far side of the lunar surface. In November, NASA's InSight lander signaled a safe landing on Mars. In December, President Trump directed the Pentagon to create a new U.S. Space Command, calling for a sixth military branch he dubbed "the Space Force." Later this month, SpaceX, Elon Musk's commercial space travel operation, is scheduled to launch its Crew Dragon capsule to the International Space Station-the first unmanned mission for NASA's commercial crew program. The launch will bring NASA one step closer to being able to send astronauts to space without relying on Russian rockets.

title: U.K. Calls in the Navy to Deter Illegal Migrants Crossing the Channel

summary: The Golden Globes brings a crop of nominees known for unconventional looks as men break out of traditional black tie. On other red carpets, he's worn unexpected ensembles such as a dress or wrap pants.

summary: President says incoming senator would have won 2012 White House bid if he had campaigned 'the way he fights me'. title: Investors Are Betting That the Fed Hits Pause on Rate Hikes
summary: Fed funds futures show high probability that interest rates will end 2019 at or below current levels. title: Canadian Court Slams Uber's Arbitration Process
summary: Ruling says ride-hailing company's dispute-resolution rules for drivers are illegal, 'unconscionable'. title: Tesla Shares Sink on Model 3 Delivery Miss, Price Cuts
summary: The electric-car maker will reduce prices by $2,000 as deliveries miss Wall Street estimates. title: Apple Warning: Seven Charts That Show the Pressure on China's Consumers
summary: The trade fight with the U.S. and rising living costs are weighing on spending. China's current economic slowdown differs from previous downturns because this time Chinese consumers are taking a hit. A less-certain economic outlook, the trade fight with the U.S., rising living costs and expectations of slower income growth are weighing on household spending. Meanwhile, slowing sales, rising costs and trade-related uncertainties are squeezing businesses' profit margins, from retailers to manufacturers.
